page.title: 13Friston Forest Ecology
page.content: Friston Forest forms a 796 hectare area of woodland,circa 1926,mainly of beech in rows 6 feet apart,alternating with rows of pine (now being felled) originally planted to protect young beeches,also some sycamores.It is a water catchment area for Eastbourne Waterworks,who lease the land to the Forestry Commision.The undergrowth is bramble and elder with a proliferation of flowering plants of the chalk downlands growing on the woodland edge It is a joy to see the re-emergence of many species of butterfly -small skipper,gatekeeper, marble white, grayling,red admiral,chalkhill blue,to name but a few. The smell of fox was quite strong in parts,evidence of rabbits abounded and one suspected the elusive badger enjoyed the protected habitat.High winds had brought down branches;these were to be collected.
